original_idea.title: Hybrid Meta-Learned Cognitive Architectures Incorporating Affective and Biomedical Feedback Loops
original_idea.Problem_Statement: Siloed research on architectural meta-learning and cognitive-affective models limits understanding of dynamic feedback mechanisms crucial for realistic mechanistic modeling.
original_idea.Motivation: Fulfills the internal gap on absent bridging concepts by developing architectures embedding closed-loop feedback from affective and biomedical signal processing into meta-learned language model cognition.
original_idea.Proposed_Method: Create architectures combining meta-learning modules with affective state estimators and biomedical feedback predictors. Use contrastive learning to align internal representations with affective and physiological signals, enabling iterative cognitive adaptation mimicking human emotional-physiological learning cycles.
original_idea.Step_by_Step_Experiment_Plan:
1) Collect multi-modal datasets linking language, emotion, and biomedical signals.
2) Develop feedback-augmented meta-learning models.
3) Train with contrastive objectives enforcing alignment of feedback states.
4) Assess mechanistic interpretability through probing feedback influence on learned cognition.
5) Compare with feedforward meta-learning baselines.
original_idea.Test_Case_Examples:
Input: Language input paired with real-time heart rate variability signal.
Expected Output: Model internally adjusts cognitive representations reflecting physiological states; mechanistic insights show effect of biomedical feedback on language understanding.
original_idea.Fallback_Plan: If joint modeling is unstable, decouple feedback loops and retrain separately or simplify affective/biomedical inputs to proxy measures (e.g., self-report).
